Historically part of the Presidio of San Francisco, Crissy Field closed as an airfield after 1974. Under Army control, the site was affected by dumping of hazardous materials.The National Park Service took control of the area in 1994 and cleaned it up, and in 2001 the Crissy Field Center opened to the public. While most buildings have been preserved as they were in the 1920s, some have been transformed into offices, retail space, and residences. If you are hungry, you can grab coffee at one of the nearby trucks. There are also trucks offering quick bites. I recommend taking in a good weekend stroll: extra early is better. Bring your own coffee or a picnic. Enjoy.

Just One Part of the Presidio

Crissy Field is in the northern portion of the Presidio of San Francisco. The Presidio is a former U.S. Army military fort on the northern tip of the San Francisco Peninsula, and is now a huge urban park that is part of the Golden Gate National Recreation Area. Crissy Field was the former U.S. Army grass airfield for the Presidio, which today is the most prominent feature you see when you arrive here. However, within the area that is called Crissy Field, you will also find some great areas to explore. If you go to the westernmost part of Crissy Field you will find a picnic area, the Warming Hut cafe, and connector paths and trails to the Golden Gate Bridge and Fort Point.

Along the northern part of Crissy Field, you have the shoreline, which has been restored, including the creation of sand dunes which provide habitat for several native species.
The recently restored tidal wetlands has a boardwalk built across the marsh to provide views of the wildlife.

Crissy Field of is a great place to fly a kite. If you don't have one, you can pick one up at one of the kite stores on Pier 39.

Crissy Field is a San Francisco Treasure!

Crissy Field has many faces depending on the weather, the time of day, any special events or not. We have lived nearby for 34 years and have watch the Presidio evolve from a military facility with an airstrip where Crissy Field is today, hence the name.

Thanks to seed monies from the generous Haas family, Crissy Field was restored to natural beauty we all enjoy today. Great beaches, amazing views, options for long walks, a quick peek, shop for unique San Francisco only items or coffee and a nosh at the "Warming Hut" between Fort Point and Crissy Field.

There is always something new to see. Water sports, little children enjoying the sand, nautical traffic on the Bay, and dogs and their masters playing ball or just chillin'.

Current projects in the Presidio can make access to Crissy Field. It is best to enter from Marina Blvd. Westbound bearing right onto Mason St. Then carefully (busy bike and jogging path) turn right into the East Beach parking lot (currently free). You could spend a few minutes or a few days (no overnight allowed). There are restrooms and a cafe at East Beach and adjacent to the Warming hut. Enjoy! Pack a picnic basket, go for a walk, ride or watch the hours unfold.
